questions.question: What is the 2024 standard deduction for a married couple filing jointly (both under 65)?
questions.explanation: The 2024 standard deduction for MFJ is $29,200. For single filers it's $14,600, and for head of household it's $21,900. Additional amounts apply for taxpayers 65+ or blind.
questions.tip: 2024 standard deduction: $29,200 MFJ, $14,600 single, $21,900 HOH.

questions.conceptTested: FUTA tax rate and wage base
questions.question: What is the FUTA tax wage base?
questions.explanation: FUTA applies to the first $7,000 of wages per employee per year. The gross rate is 6.0%, but a 5.4% credit applies if state unemployment taxes are paid timely, resulting in a net 0.6% rate.
questions.tip: FUTA: $7,000 wage base, 6% gross rate, 0.6% net with state credit.

questions.question: For capital gains purposes, an asset is considered long-term if held for:
questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain treatment requires holding the asset for more than one year. Assets held exactly one year or less are short-term. Holding period begins the day after acquisition.
questions.tip: Long-term: MORE than 1 year. Count from day after purchase.

questions.question: What is the 2024 HSA contribution limit for family coverage?
questions.explanation: The 2024 HSA contribution limit is $8,300 for family coverage ($4,150 for self-only). Those 55+ can contribute an additional $1,000 catch-up. Contributions are tax-deductible and grow tax-free.
questions.tip: 2024 HSA: $8,300 family, $4,150 self-only, +$1,000 catch-up (55+).

questions.question: The lifetime gift tax exemption uses the same exemption amount as:
questions.explanation: The gift, estate, and GST exemptions are all unified at $13.61 million (2024). Lifetime taxable gifts reduce the estate tax exemption dollar-for-dollar. GST has a separate but equal exemption.
questions.tip: Unified exemption: Gift = Estate = GST ($13.61M each for 2024).

questions.question: Foreign taxes paid can be treated as either:

options.D: A credit or excluded from income

questions.explanation: Taxpayers can elect to treat foreign income taxes as either a credit (reducing tax dollar-for-dollar up to the limit) or an itemized deduction (reducing taxable income). The credit is usually more beneficial.
questions.tip: Foreign taxes: Credit or deduction election. Credit usually better.

questions.question: An S corporation can have a maximum of how many shareholders?
questions.explanation: S corporations are limited to 100 shareholders. Family members (within 6 generations) can elect to be treated as one shareholder for this count. Exceeding 100 terminates the S election.
questions.tip: S corp: 100 shareholder max. Family can elect single-shareholder treatment.

questions.question: A partnership's required tax year is generally:
questions.explanation: Partnerships must use the tax year of partners owning majority interest, or if none, principal partners' year, or calendar year. Section 444 election allows fiscal year with required payment.
questions.tip: Partnership year: Majority partners' year → principal partners' year → calendar year.

questions.question: For divorce agreements executed after December 31, 2018, alimony payments are:

options.A: Deductible by payor, taxable to recipient
options.B: Not deductible by payor, not taxable to recipient

questions.explanation: TCJA eliminated the alimony deduction for post-2018 divorce agreements. The payor cannot deduct payments, and the recipient doesn't include them in income. Pre-2019 agreements retain old rules unless modified.
questions.tip: Post-2018 alimony: No deduction, no inclusion. Pre-2019 agreements grandfathered.

questions.question: What is the bonus depreciation percentage for qualified property placed in service in 2024?
questions.explanation: Bonus depreciation is phasing out: 100% (2017-2022), 80% (2023), 60% (2024), 40% (2025), 20% (2026), 0% (2027+). Used property can qualify if new to the taxpayer.
questions.tip: 2024 bonus depreciation: 60%. Phases down 20% per year until 2027.

questions.question: Charitable bequests in an estate are:

options.B: Unlimited deduction from the gross estate
options.C: Subject to the same limits as income tax charitable deductions

questions.explanation: The estate tax charitable deduction is unlimited. Bequests to qualified charities are fully deductible from the gross estate, regardless of size. This differs from income tax limitations.
questions.tip: Estate charitable deduction: Unlimited. No AGI-type limits.

questions.question: The federal corporate income tax rate under TCJA is:
questions.explanation: TCJA established a flat 21% corporate rate, replacing the prior graduated rates (15%-35%). This rate applies to all taxable income regardless of amount. Personal service corporations also pay 21%.
questions.tip: Corporate rate: Flat 21% under TCJA. No more graduated rates.

questions.question: The AMT exemption phases out at what rate as AMTI increases above the threshold?
questions.explanation: The AMT exemption phases out at 25% of AMTI exceeding the threshold. For MFJ, the exemption ($133,300 for 2024) begins phasing out at $1,218,700 and is fully eliminated at around $1,752,000.
questions.tip: AMT exemption phase-out: 25% of AMTI over threshold. Fully eliminated at high income.

questions.question: Private foundations must distribute approximately what percentage of net investment assets annually?
questions.explanation: Private foundations must make qualifying distributions of approximately 5% of net investment assets annually to avoid an excise tax on undistributed income. Qualifying distributions include grants and administrative expenses.
questions.tip: Private foundation: ~5% annual distribution required. Excise tax on undistributed income.

questions.question: Which factor is typically most important in determining state tax domicile?

options.A: Number of days in the state
options.B: Intent to make the state a permanent home

questions.explanation: Domicile is determined by intent to establish a permanent home. While physical factors (days present, license, voter registration, bank accounts) are evidence of intent, the underlying intent is the key factor.
questions.tip: Domicile = intent + facts showing permanent home. Physical presence is one factor among many.

questions.question: Under SECURE Act rules, most non-spouse beneficiaries must empty an inherited IRA within:
questions.explanation: The SECURE Act requires most non-spouse beneficiaries to withdraw all funds within 10 years of the original owner's death. Eligible designated beneficiaries (surviving spouse, minor children, disabled, etc.) can still use life expectancy.
questions.tip: SECURE Act: 10-year rule for most non-spouse beneficiaries. RMDs may also apply during the period.

questions.question: Which benefit can be offered through a Section 125 cafeteria plan?
questions.explanation: Cafeteria plans can offer health insurance, dependent care FSA, HSA contributions, and certain other benefits. Long-term care insurance, retirement contributions, and educational assistance cannot be offered through Section 125.
questions.tip: Section 125: Health, dental, vision, dependent care, HSA. Not LTC, retirement, or education.

questions.question: A taxpayer has Section 1231 gains of $50,000 and Section 1231 losses of $20,000. How is the net gain treated?
questions.explanation: Net Section 1231 gains are treated as long-term capital gains. However, the 5-year lookback rule recharacterizes gain as ordinary income to the extent of prior Section 1231 losses that offset ordinary income.
questions.tip: Section 1231: Net gains = LTCG (subject to 5-year lookback). Net losses = ordinary.

questions.question: A >2% S corporation shareholder-employee cannot receive which benefit tax-free?

options.C: Meals and lodging for employer convenience
options.D: All of the above are taxable

questions.explanation: Over-2% shareholders cannot receive certain fringe benefits tax-free: health insurance, group term life over $50K, and some others. Retirement contributions are allowed. The cost becomes W-2 income but may be deductible elsewhere.
questions.tip: >2% S corp shareholder: Health insurance and group term life taxable. Retirement OK.

questions.question: Income in respect of a decedent (IRD) receives:

options.B: No step-up; taxed when received by beneficiary

questions.explanation: IRD (items like IRA distributions, unpaid wages, installment sale receivables) does NOT receive a step-up in basis. The beneficiary pays income tax when received. An IRD deduction may offset some estate tax paid on the same income.
questions.tip: IRD: No basis step-up. Taxed to beneficiary when received. Section 691(c) deduction available.

questions.question: A taxpayer with significant investment income should:

options.B: Make estimated tax payments or increase W-4 withholding
options.D: Investment income is not subject to estimated payments

questions.explanation: Investment income is not subject to withholding, so taxpayers must make estimated payments or increase W-4 withholding to avoid underpayment penalties. Withholding is treated as paid evenly throughout the year.
questions.tip: Investment income: Plan for estimated payments. Increasing W-4 withholding is an alternative.

questions.question: The TCJA transition tax (Section 965) applied to:

options.B: Accumulated deferred foreign earnings of CFCs

questions.explanation: Section 965 imposed a one-time transition tax on accumulated post-1986 deferred foreign earnings of CFCs (and certain foreign corporations) when the U.S. moved to a territorial system. Rates were 15.5% for cash and 8% for non-cash assets.
questions.tip: Section 965: One-time transition tax on deferred foreign earnings. 15.5% cash, 8% other.

questions.question: Suspended passive losses carry forward:

options.C: Indefinitely until used or activity disposed
options.D: Until the next profitable year only

questions.explanation: Suspended passive losses carry forward indefinitely until offset by passive income or released upon complete disposition of the activity. There is no time limit on the carryforward.
questions.tip: Passive loss carryforward: Indefinite. Released on disposition of activity.

questions.question: Under the centralized partnership audit rules (BBA), who represents the partnership in IRS audits?
questions.explanation: The BBA replaced the tax matters partner with the partnership representative, who has sole authority to act on behalf of the partnership in audits and proceedings. Partners have limited ability to challenge representative actions.
questions.tip: BBA audits: Partnership representative has sole authority. Must be designated annually.

questions.question: Which of the following is a fully refundable tax credit?
questions.explanation: The earned income credit is fully refundable—the full credit is paid even if it exceeds tax liability. The child tax credit is partially refundable ($1,700). The others are nonrefundable.
questions.tip: Refundable credits: EIC (full), child tax credit (partial), additional child tax credit, AOC (40%).

questions.question: A taxpayer materially participated in activity A last year (releasing prior suspended losses). This year, they do not materially participate. The activity generates income. How is the income treated?
questions.explanation: Each year's material participation is determined independently. Without material participation this year, the activity is passive, and income is passive. Prior year status doesn't carry over.
questions.tip: Material participation: Determined annually. Each year stands on its own.

questions.question: A QTIP trust provides the surviving spouse with:

options.B: All income for life but no control over remainder

questions.explanation: QTIP trusts give the surviving spouse all income for life, but the first spouse to die controls where the remainder goes (often to children from prior marriage). QTIP qualifies for marital deduction but is included in survivor's estate.
questions.tip: QTIP: Income to spouse for life; donor controls remainder. Marital deduction now, estate inclusion at second death.

questions.question: Under Section 1061, for a carried interest to receive long-term capital gain treatment, the underlying assets must be held for:
questions.explanation: Section 1061 requires a 3-year holding period (instead of 1 year) for gains attributable to carried interests to qualify for LTCG rates. This affects private equity, venture capital, and hedge fund managers.
questions.tip: Carried interest: 3-year hold for LTCG. Regular investments still 1 year.

questions.question: A C corporation distributes appreciated property (basis $30,000, FMV $100,000) as a dividend. What are the tax consequences to the corporation?
questions.explanation: Under Section 311(b), a C corporation recognizes gain on distributions of appreciated property as if the property were sold at FMV. Gain = $100,000 - $30,000 = $70,000. The shareholder receives dividend income of $100,000 (FMV).
questions.tip: C corp property distribution: Corp recognizes gain as if sold at FMV. Shareholder dividend = FMV.

questions.question: The FDII deduction for C corporations effectively reduces the tax rate on foreign-derived intangible income to approximately:
questions.explanation: The Section 250 FDII deduction (37.5% of FDII through 2025, then 21.875%) reduces the effective rate on FDII to 13.125% (21% × (1 - 37.5%)). This incentivizes keeping IP and related income in the U.S.
questions.tip: FDII: 37.5% deduction → 13.125% effective rate. Counterpart to GILTI.

questions.question: The throwback rules for accumulation distributions from domestic trusts were:

options.B: Repealed for domestic trusts, but apply to foreign trusts
options.C: Still in full effect for all trusts

questions.explanation: The throwback rules (taxing beneficiaries on accumulated income plus interest) were repealed for domestic trusts in 1997. They still apply to foreign trusts, making distributions of accumulated income potentially very expensive.
questions.tip: Throwback rules: Repealed for domestic trusts. Still apply to foreign trusts.

questions.question: A 'top-hat' nonqualified deferred compensation plan is exempt from most ERISA requirements because it covers:

options.B: Only management or highly compensated employees

questions.explanation: Top-hat plans are unfunded plans maintained primarily for management or highly compensated employees. They're exempt from ERISA's participation, vesting, and funding rules, allowing flexibility in design.
questions.tip: Top-hat plan: Management/HCE only. Exempt from most ERISA rules. Must be unfunded.

questions.question: Under the codified economic substance doctrine, a transaction lacking economic substance can result in:
questions.explanation: Section 6662(b)(6) imposes a 20% penalty (40% if not adequately disclosed) for transactions lacking economic substance. The penalty is strict liability—no reasonable cause defense. The doctrine requires meaningful change to economic position plus business purpose.
questions.tip: Economic substance: 20% penalty (40% undisclosed). No reasonable cause defense. Strict liability.

questions.question: In a consolidated return, gain from intercompany sales between group members is:

options.B: Deferred until the property leaves the group

questions.explanation: Intercompany transactions are deferred in consolidated returns. Gain is recognized when a triggering event occurs (property leaves the group, member leaves group, etc.). This prevents tax on internal transfers.
questions.tip: Consolidated intercompany gains: Deferred until triggered (asset or member leaves group).

questions.question: Which TCJA provision is scheduled to sunset after 2025?
questions.explanation: Many individual TCJA provisions sunset after 2025: the doubled estate exemption (returns to ~$6M), increased standard deduction, $10K SALT cap, suspended personal exemptions, etc. The 21% corporate rate is permanent.
questions.tip: TCJA sunset (2026): Estate exemption drops, SALT cap expires, individual rates revert. Corp rate stays.
